Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Processing and Assembly of Devices with Tailored Magnetic Properties

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nanomaterials, materials with features ranging from 1-100 nm, have been developed with many unique properties, and a variety of techniques have been developed to produce these materials in large volumes at low cost. However to date, we lack commercial methods to incorporate these materials and their unique properties into novel devices, or to build these functions into materials over larger length scales. One particularly exciting collection of nanomaterials are composites that can use electricity to change magnetic properties and vice-versa. These materials could lead to the realization of new types of electronic devices, including new types of memory and data storage. In this project we seek to develop novel methods for synthesizing and assembling these materials into larger-scale optical devices that could find application in sensors, optical integrated circuits, and in data transmission and storage. Importantly, this effort includes research to measure and verify that these materials behave as designed once integrated into a manufactured device. Such quality control, especially monitoring during manufacturing, is critical to enable commercialization of these materials. This project combines the efforts of materials scientists at the University of Florida and physicists at the University of South Carolina to provide a unique interdisciplinary research environment for student researchers, critical for not only discovery but for future societal benefit for materials with properties that span multiple traditional scientific disciplines.

This project addresses synthesis and assembly of devices built from multiferroic composite materials, i.e. materials that exhibit at least two, and sometimes three types of ferroic ordering in the same phase. In this project, activities center on biphasic fibers that combine a piezoelectric and a magnetostrictive material. The figure of merit for these multiferroics is the magnetoelectric coefficient, which measures the magnitude of the electric field generated when the multiferroic material is placed in an applied magnetic field. Using magnetic annealing and magnetic-field-directed self-assembly, research efforts will develop materials with enhanced magnetoelectric coefficients and assemble them into novel optical devices. In parallel, novel process metrologies will be implemented to characterize the properties of the fibers and devices built from them. These measurements will identify systematics and quantify magnetoelectric coupling in materials that are not amenable to more established characterization methodologies.

Institution.Name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

Performance_Institution.Name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

Intellectual Merit

This project was a collaboration between the University of South Carolina (USC) Physics and Astronomy and the University of Florida (UF) Department of Materials Science and Engineering. The team at UF uses a technique called Electrospinning to prepare small fibers that combine two novel materials, a ferrite, such as lodestone or a meteorite, that responds to magnetic fields, and a ferroelectric, a material that responds to an electric fields. Coupled together, these materials enable one to generate an electric field by applying a magnetic field, and could replace a battery with a magnet in certain applications. Working with the team at UF the USC team suspended these fibers in a liquid solution containing a polymer. Thin sheets of the polymer were creating with randomly oriented fibers. Applying a magnetic to the polymer before it cured causes the fibers to align end-to-end and form chains (Figures Chained Fibers 1 and 2). We were able to understand and model how these fibers chain as a function of the fiber concentration in solution and as a function of magnetic field strength during curing. We compared our results with prior experiments done with magnetic nanoparticles, and found interesting deviations in how the chaining occurs in fiber-like materials.

Once cured these films can be studied to understand how the fibers assemble, and also to understand their magnetic properties (Figure Scattered Moke). Here we used polarized laser light and scattered the light off of the fibers after chaining and curing the polymer. By measuring this scattered light as we changed the size of a magnetic field, we were able to measure how the magnetic part of the fibers responds to a magnetic field, a critical measurement to ultimately understanding how the electric and magnetic properties are connected in these materials.

Finally, we explored what happens when the magnetic field is applied perpendicular to the surface of the polymer film, i.e. we aligned the fibers vertically. As shown in the Figure Vertical Fibers, we were able to chain the fibers vertically and force them to come out of the polymer film. This type of assembly could allow for electrical connection to the fibers as well as provide a mechanism to employ the polymer as a magnetically-activated filtration membrane for low-power filtration applications.

Broader Impacts

By understanding how to assemble these materials and how to deploy them in a polymer, as well as how their magnetic and electrical properties are related, we can help develop smart materials for applications where it is difficult to obtain electric fields, i.e. without having a battery or other source of electric power. 


Last Modified: 12/13/2017
Modified by: Thomas Crawford

The team at UF uses a technique called Electrospinning to prepare small fibers that combine two novel materials, a ferrite, such as lodestone or a meteorite, that responds to magnetic fields, and a ferroelectric, a material that responds to an electric fields.
